content.text: English Title: Service Oriented Software Development
Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
Faculty conducting the course: Information Technology, Suite 1310, Building A1, National Economics University, 207 Giai Phong str., Hai Ba Trung dist., Ha Noi, Vietnam.
Lecturers: Dr. Phạm Minh Hoàn, tel: 0949263666, email: hoanpm@neu.edu.vn
Dr. Lưu Minh Tuấn, tel: 0904143460, email: tuanlm@neu.edu.vn

The module provides knowledge about service-oriented software development concepts, architecture, methods and tools so that students can apply them to practical problems during their studies as well as after graduation. In the first part, the module introduces an overview of service-oriented software development and techniques in service-oriented software development. The next part introduces the service-oriented architecture model and foundation, principles and properties of service-oriented software systems. The module also provides details about the platform, technology, process and how to develop Web services: SOAP and RESTful. Finally, the module also provides knowledge about the system life cycle, system building strategies, service-oriented modeling approach and basic steps to build a service-oriented system.
[1] Mario-Leander Reimer (2018), Building RESTful Web Services with Java EE 8, Packt Publishing.
[2]. Robert Daigneau (2011), Service Design Patterns: Fundamental Design Solutions for SOAP/WSDL and RESTful Web services, Addison-Wesley Professional.
[3] Leonard Richarson, Mike Amundsen (2013), RESTfull Web APIs, O'Reilly Media.

content.text: Students are required to fully take part in class lectures and activities.
Students are allowed to be absent for a maximum of 30% of the class hours. Students who are absent over 30% are not qualified to take the final exam.
The course is carried out with respect to both lecturer and students. All behavior that might adversely affect the stakeholders is prohibited.
Students need to be in class on time. Students being late for more than 10 minutes will not be eligible to take part in the session.
Cellphones, laptops, tablet are only accepted for the purposes of taking notes of the lectures, preparing course assignments, not for another entertainment purposes while in class duration.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.

Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

full_text:
COURSE SYLLABUS
(Issued attached Decision of NEU’s President, , , 2023)
English Title: Service Oriented Software Development
Code: CNTT1190
Level Of Education: Undergraduate
Type Of Education: Full-Time
Credits: 3
Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
+ Lecture: 20 hrs
+ Presentation and Discussion: 5 hrs
+ Exercise and discussion: 23 hrs
+ Self-study: 99 hrs.
Prerequisite course(s): CNTT1128, TIKT1130.
Faculty conducting the course: Information Technology, Suite 1310, Building A1, National Economics University, 207 Giai Phong str., Hai Ba Trung dist., Ha Noi, Vietnam.
Lecturers: Dr. Phạm Minh Hoàn, tel: 0949263666, email: hoanpm@neu.edu.vn
Dr. Lưu Minh Tuấn, tel: 0904143460, email: tuanlm@neu.edu.vn
Kind of the course:
The module provides knowledge about service-oriented software development concepts, architecture, methods and tools so that students can apply them to practical problems during their studies as well as after graduation. In the first part, the module introduces an overview of service-oriented software development and techniques in service-oriented software development. The next part introduces the service-oriented architecture model and foundation, principles and properties of service-oriented software systems. The module also provides details about the platform, technology, process and how to develop Web services: SOAP and RESTful. Finally, the module also provides knowledge about the system life cycle, system building strategies, service-oriented modeling approach and basic steps to build a service-oriented system.
[1] Mario-Leander Reimer (2018), Building RESTful Web Services with Java EE 8, Packt Publishing.
[2]. Robert Daigneau (2011), Service Design Patterns: Fundamental Design Solutions for SOAP/WSDL and RESTful Web services, Addison-Wesley Professional.
[3] Leonard Richarson, Mike Amundsen (2013), RESTfull Web APIs, O'Reilly Media.
Table 4. Course goals
Table 5. Course learning outcomes (CLOs)
* Assessment methods:
- Grading: 10
- Average score of course is the total points of rubrics multiplied by the respective weight of each rubric.
* Assessment summary:
Table 6. Course assessment
Table 8. Lesson Plan for the course
9. COURSE REQUIREMENTS AND EXPECTATION
9.1. Attendance Requirements
Students are required to fully take part in class lectures and activities.
Students are allowed to be absent for a maximum of 30% of the class hours. Students who are absent over 30% are not qualified to take the final exam.
9.2. In-class Behavior Requirements
The course is carried out with respect to both lecturer and students. All behavior that might adversely affect the stakeholders is prohibited.
Students need to be in class on time. Students being late for more than 10 minutes will not be eligible to take part in the session.
Cellphones, laptops, tablet are only accepted for the purposes of taking notes of the lectures, preparing course assignments, not for another entertainment purposes while in class duration.
9.3. Requirements for in-class behaviour
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
